text: (shouting, in unison) ..Hip hip hooray!!! Crystal clanking. Corks popping. Behind the TOASTMASTER, an enormous BANNER: "Victory to the Union"
A grand CELEBRATION instantly denoting prestige and influ all powerful and all for Union.
Is he here, yet?

No. But half his cabinet is. REVEAL: FREDERICK AIKEN, now 28, aged a bit by events, jo again by NICHOLAS BAKER, now minus his leg. Another hotsh WILLIAM HAMILTON, is present too. They've all had a few. Aiken scans faces. Notes players. POWER BROKERS abound.
There's Interior...the Postmaster... INSERT: GRAYBEARDS, as Aiken identifies the members of LINCOLN'S CABINET, Like positions around an infield.
Treasury...Navy...and War
Secretary Stanton, where?
Aiken points to EDWIN STANTON, 50, imperious, chest lengt beard, eyes concealed behind tiny, gold-rimmed glasses.
I'd give my eye-teeth to meet him. Aiken begins to beeline towards Stanton, then stops.
Aren't you coming?
Just like that?
Are you mad? You can't approach Edwin Stanton without an introduction.
Watch how it's done. Unless, you'd prefer to meet him too? Baker nods. Aiken moves to help his one-legged friend.
I can do it myself.
Like hell, you couldn't walk straight with two. A BOOMING VOICE catches Aiken from behind.
Mr. Aiken, I've been to creation and back looking for you. Aiken turns toward a familiar voice.
Baker, Hamilton... May I introduce the distinguished Senator from Maryland -- Mr. Reverdy Johnson. REVEAL: REVERDY JOHNSON, early 50's, a thorn in anyone's side. Blind in his left eye. Very southern.
A great honor, Senator
(slurred from drinking) May I say, sir...you were our first I mean, our finest Attorney General.
Honor's mine, gentlemen. You've done this nation proud. Glad to see y'all are enjoyin' this evenin'. Reverdy Johnson winks at Baker with his good eye.
Country needs you boys more than ever to put it back together. Reverdy Johnson spots several GRAYBEARDS passing by.
Gentlemen, would you excuse us a moment? They're some folks I reckon' my new associate ought to meet. The Senator leads Aiken away. Hamilton watches with envy.
I reckon Fred has to if he's to be considered seriously.
Yes, Hamilton, some of us do have to work for a living...
Reverdy ushers Aiken inside the club's inner sanctum line with PORTRAITS of its past luminaries JEFFERSON, MADISON.
Quite a turnout.
Victory is like shit to flies, Freddie. One whiff is all it takes. sarcastically) . Mr. Secretary, such a delightful surprise. REVEAL: EDWIN STANTON puffing furiously on a FAT CIGAR.
Life's full of ‘em, Senator
Frederick Aiken. Of course, you're familiar with our venerable War Secretary, Edwin Stanton.
Yes, of course. It's a great pleasure, sir.
I understand you took two bullets at Gettysburg, Colonel, and never quit the field. The pleasure is mine Stanton warmly clanks Aiken's champagne glass. Aiken beam
We can always use a loyal man like you over at the War Department.
My godson works for me now, Ed. It's time to heal the nation -- not wage war.
Depending on whose side you're on.
One needn't be a Yankee to be for Union same as you.
Well then, I dare say, the enemy is never far from hand. An AIDE hands Stanton a NOTE. Stanton reads it.
Is everything alright? ; _ STANTON ; President Lincoln sends his regrets -- seems Mrs. Lincoln made other plans. ...The SOUND of laughter.
As TWO ACTORS perform the farce, "Our American Cousin." O is dressed as a Victorian DANDY; the other, as an eccentr BACKWOODSMAN. The setting is an English drawing room. ...The SOURCE of laughter

As ABRAHAM and MARY LINCOLN enjoy the performance. The PRESIDENT tilts back-and-forth in a crimson rocking c The FIRST LADY lovingly drapes her hand across his knee. A couple in their twenties, MAJOR RATHBONE and CLARA HARR are seated nearby. ...A P.0.V on the LINCOLNS and their GUESTS.

...A TALL MAN with a BLACK FELT HAT, spying too.

Only, he's watching the ENTRANCE to a stately, three-stor MANSION from across Washington's Lafayette Square. Private Residence o Secretary of State Frederick Seward The Tall Man pulls a BOWIE KNIFE from beneath his felt ha a REVOLVER from his overcoat, and crosses the street. He mounts the mansion's FRONT STOOP and rings the door BE A BUTLER answers...
...The DOOR swinging open. Only, instead of the Tall Man entering, it's a SMALL MAN, wearing a BEAVER SKIN CAP...

...And instead of the Mansion's entrance, we're now insid plush HOTEL LOBBY, crowded with GUESTS. The Residence o Vice President Andrew Johnson The Short Man shuffles UNCOMFORTABLY amidst all the opule his EYES flashing to a CLOCK on the WALL, which reads: 10:15 P.M. ...The sudden POP of a CHAMPAGNE CORK.
As Baker opens a fresh bottle. Aiken has rejoined his mat
Good to see the last four years did someone good. REVEALING: the stunning CATHERINE MORGAN, early 20's.
Hello, Catherine.
Too grown up to call me Katie anymore?
You're the one who's grown up. Catherine warmly greets Baker, Hamilton. Glances at Aiken
Johnny Reb' get his tongue?
How are you, Katie?
Not a letter from you in 18 months. I should ask how you are?
We didn't see much I wanted to share.
(re. Hamilton) Bill wrote me twice a month.
That so?
Just checking in with the home front.
One's imagination wanders when you haven't a word. ; AIKEN ; ; Might we have one now - in private? Catherine nods, turns back to Baker and Hamilton.
Sure good to see you, boys. Aiken escorts Catherine away, fingers clasped. Hamilton looks on with envy. Baker pops a cigar. LIGHTS a match...
...The startling BANG of a pistol. An EXPLOSION, like the deep POP of a heavy, paper bag. Th a BURST of smoke. And finally, a THUD, bullet against bon

As Lincoln's rocking ceases, and his chin pitches into hi chest. MARY LINCOLN clutches his neck to keep him upright Booth stands a few paces behind -- a brass DERRINGER in h right hand; a DAGGER in his left. Major Rathbone dunges for Booth. His left ankle fractures badly above the in-step. H limps across the stage, stopping just long enough to YELL
Sic Semper Tyrannis! Revenge for the South. Then, rushes past dazed ACTORS, and escapes into the WING
Just as Booth's TALL ACCOMPLICE bursts out the FRONT DOOR his hands dripping with blood.

TRACKING through the house to REVEAL what's left behind: -- First, the Tall Accomplice 's BLACK FELT HAT tipped on side, at the bottom of the staircase; -- Then, a GUARD, coughing blood, writhing along the stai -- Followed by an ARMY AIDE, badly hurt and bleeding, slu on the second floor landing; -- Next, SEWARD'S SON, alive, but unconscious with a frac skull, inside a bedroom doorway; -- And lastly, SECRETARY of STATE FREDERICK SEWARD, in be gasping for air and bleeding, from a near-fatal facial ga

Booth's SHORT ACCOMPLICE, with the BEAVER SKIN HAT, is fr with fear on a bar stool, his eyes leaden with drink. A SOLDIER casts a suspicious glance his way, causing the fearful Associate to flee out the front door, as we CUT T

Just as Aiken is placing an ENGAGEMENT RING on Catherine' finger. Baker, now piss drunk, celebrates his mate's new union by drinking champagne from his artificial leg. A SOLDIER rushes past knocking Baker's leg out of his han
What the hell? Suddenly, Secretary Stanton is whisked away under heavy security. Followed by several more party-goers. Hamilton approaches Aiken and Catherine, his face ashen.
What is it, Bill?

They've attacked Lincoln - and the Secretary of State too. Aiken registers the shock. As Baker tries to locate his l amidst the tumult, we DISSOLVE TO -- A near-riotous crowd assembled outside PETERSEN HOUSE, a townhouse across the street from Ford's Theater Torches ablaze. Vengeance on many lips. We TRACK with Union MAJOR H.W. SMITH inside --

A small, sloped BEDROOM adorned with pastoral prints. It an unspectacular setting for a spectacular end. DOCTORS, CABINET MEMBERS and a PRESBYTERIAN MINISTER surr PRESIDENT LINCOLN, who is laying diagonally across a bed far too short -- his bare feet angling over the edge. The only sound is of Lincoln's near-final gasps. Major Smith passes a PHYSICIAN carrying a bundle of bloodstained towels. Smith continues down the HALLWAY, in An adjacent SITTING ROOM, now functioning as a WAR ROOM - SEVERAL ACTORS, still in costume, are being interrogated. Major Rathbone is trying to console his fiancee, Clara Ha Her clothes are soaked with Lincoln's blood. Major Smith surveys the chaos -- revealing EDWIN STANTON in charge. Stanton beckons him inside a CLOAK ROOM.
It was the actor, John Wilkes Booth.
Are you certain?
They all know him from the theater Pointing to the ACTORS being interrogated in the other ro
What about the other assassins?
The only name mentioned so far is an acquaintance of Booth's -- a young man named, John Surratt.
What do we know about him?
Twenty-one years of age. Lives here in the city with his family. Mother runs a boardinghouse. That's it.  10.

I guarantee he's a Confederate. Find him. Find all of them. (a beat) I want this city closed down. Nothing leaves Washington without my authorization. No trains. No boats. If any one of these assassins gets South of the Potomac or up into Canada, he'll never be found. Major Smith exits. Another AIDE approaches.
Sir, the Vice President wishes to pay his respects.
He may leave that hotel only when I say it's safe to do so. The Aide nods, begins to exit.

(calls out) And keep him away from the liquor. He's liable to drink himself into a stupor with fright! MARY LINCOLN lets out a piercing wail from the adjacent r FULL SCREEN: On President Lincoln's motionless FACE accompanied by more screams. PULL BACK: to reveal the screams are coming from a LOCOMO whistling into the night, wrapped in black bunting. Linco face is actually a PORTRAIT fixed to the front of the tra Lincoln's COFFIN is inside.

As the train builds speed, we INTERCUT between: LINCOLN'S DEIFICATION -- Newspaper headlines chronicle th 1700 mile funeral procession from Washington, D.C. to Springfield, Illinois, his hometown and inal resting plac "40,000 in the Rain in Cleveland"..."300,000 at Independe Hall"..."Half a Million Along Broadway" STANTON'S REIGN of TERROR -- The ROUND-UP of the alleged ASSASSINS. Ford's Theater is chained shut; DOZENS are arrested in saloons, churches, outhouses and homes. BOOTH is cornered inside a BURNING FARMHOUSE. He is shot and killed. Another accomplice, DAVID HEROLD, surrenders. The FINAL IMAGES shown are of -- A slender three-story TOWNHOUSE along a residential stree All appears peaceful. No sign of the hysteria beyond. Suddenly, the FRONT DOOR bursts open.  11. SIX SOLDIERS escort a MYSTERY WOMAN, 45, down the front s while her DAUGHTER, 22, is restrained by several troops. The Mystery Woman is placed inside a JAIL CELL. The DOOR slammed shut behind, plunging her world into darkness.
FADE UP: On the AMERICAN FLAG
A_ glimpse of the unmistakable CAPITOL DOME, its American flag still flying at half-mast for Lincoln.

Aiken races inside the ROTUNDA, nearly knocking over an ELDERLY SENATOR in his path. He sprints across STATUARY HALL, past the busts of our Founding Fathers. Aiken continues down a long HALLWAY lined with Senate off a stack of legal briefs virtually spilling out of his han Finally, he enters through an enormous OAK DOOR bearing t brass inscription: United States Senator (Maryland) Reverdy Johnson He finds REVERDY JOHNSON already long in wait.
Mornin', young man. Nice of you to show up.
My sincerest apologies, Senator. I was just finishing the land conveyance you requested. The Senator performs a cursory review.
You've been up all night on this?
Most of it, sir.
Plus some carousing with your mates?
Just a bit.  12.
I appreciate your enthusiasm, Freddie. I just hope you haven't run yourself ragged, nor forgotten the Assassins' Trial begins tomorrow.
No one's talking about anything else. My mates and I hope to squirrel a seat.
Well, you've 'squirreled' a chair instead.
How's that, sir? The Senator hands Aiken a stack of papers.
I'm trying the case. You'll be assisting -- my second chair.
But I thought the government was planning a military court-martial.
Indeed. Secretary Stanton picked himself nine generals to serve as judges -- all for Union and all riends of the late President.
buttoning

fastening INT. U.S. the MILITARY COMMISSION, preparing for trial -- their Union uniforms, pinning on their medals. REVERDY JOHNSON (V.O. In fact, he's chosen one of Lincoln's pallbearers to head the Commission. the bearded and bespectacled GENERAL HUNTER, 62, his pearl-handled saber to his hip.
As Aiken and Reverdy Johnson continue their conversation through the hallway of the Capitol.
If it's a military trial, won't the War Department be handling the prosecution?
Stanton's put his most trusted in charge of the case -- the Chief Adjutant General, Joseph Holt.  13.

REVEALING Edwin Stanton's devoted aide-de-camp, JOSEPH HO 56, as he devises a strategy with the War Secretary. The corner features a shrine to Lincoln from Ford's Theat Lincoln's rocking chair, top hat and coat -- blood-staine
As Aiken and Reverdy descend the steps, which are now lin with folks hawking LINCOLN MEMORABILIA -- death portraits supposed locks of hair...
Then, what are we to do?
Defend one of the eight.
One of the Assassins?
Alleged, counselor. Reverdy Johnson holds up a NOTE.
I received a letter this morning from the lady, the one with the boardinghouse... a Mrs. Mary... The Senator searches the note for Mary's last name. Aiken is quick with the answer.
Surratt.
She says I once helped her late husband on a tax matter.
But you don't recall?
Truth is I don't remember ever laying eyes on her late husband or her. But she's from Maryland too...
Sir, the government believes her son, John, was Booth's right-hand.
If they suspect her son, then they ought to try him.  14.
I've heard they have 250 agents out looking for him. Senator, you don't Know her. But you're still defending er?
Young man, it matters none if I've heard of Mary Surratt -- or her son. She's entitled to a defense. So, I shall defend her! Reverdy continues onward as Aiken remains frozen in place
Mary Eugenia Jenkins Surratt...
As we REVEAL -- MARY SURRATT, 45 -- dressed from head-to- in black, her face concealed by a heavy veil. (She is the Mystery Woman shown earlier being led from her home.)

You are charged with conspiring, aiding and abetting... GENERAL HUNTER, 62, reads from parchment, his saber dangl by his side. He is surrounded by the members of the MILIT COMMISSION, nine grizzled Union vets, high-ranking all.

The late John Wilkes Booth -- and his Confederates... SEVEN 'CONFEDERATES' are revealed beside Mary Surratt as each name is called. They are seated inside a raised PRISONERS' DOCK. All are in their twenties or early thirt

David Herold, Michael O'Laughlin, Edward Span fer, Dr. Samuel Mudd Samuel Arnold, George Atzerodt and Lewis Payne... (NOTE: Lewis Payne is readily identifiable as Booth's Tal Accomplice; George Atzerodt as his shorter one.)

In a treasonous plot to murder President Abraham Lincoln; Vice President Andrew Johnson; and Secretary of State William Seward... The PACKED courtroom stirs with each charge. Hastily converting a BARRACKS into a courtroom inside the prison for security reasons, the chamber measures only 55 feet x 20-feet with an 11-foot high ceiling. The WALLS ar freshly white-washed. All FOUR WINDOWS are barred.  15. The PRESS and JUDGES are seated at long TABLES cutting th room lengthwise. The GALLERY (by invitation only) are cra in at the rear. ARMED SOLDIERS are stationed throughout.
Pursuant to special orders #211 and #216, does the accused wish to offer a plea? The veiled defendant is frozen with fear.
What say you, madam? Guilty or not. Mary Surratt removes her veil revealing a handsome face.
I am innocent.
Of all charges?
Yes, sir. I most certainly am.

In that case, as each defendant has entered a not guilty plea, we'll begin with the woman first -- the United States versus Mary Surratt. General Hunter looks to the PROSECUTION table positioned advantageously by his side.
Major Holt, please proceed. Joseph Holt rises to begin, his chest laden with medals. is surrounded by a HALF-DOZEN ASSOCIATES.
Just a moment, your honor Reverdy Johnson rises directly in front of Mary Surratt. Frederick Aiken, his lone associate, remains seated besid
What is it, Senator?
I wish to request an adjournment.
An adjournment! We just got here. Even the LAWYERS defending the other prisoners seem shock
The defendant has been in custod for over a month. But wasn't allowed to contact counsel until yesterday. (MORE )
I've still not been permitted to meet with her.
Your honor, a delay will only serve to prolong the nation's sorrow.
My learned colleague, you've had four weeks to prepare your case. No doubt, assisted by the entire War Department. I believe the defendant is entitled to equal consideration.
Senator, our fellow citizens must be allowed to put this tra edy to rest. The sooner we dispose of this case, the better for everyone.
Everyone but my client.
Proceed, Major. Holt rises.
In that case, I move for termination.
Termination! Aiken turns to the Gallery spotting Baker, Hamilton and Catherine. Aiken looks as if he'd rather be anywhere else
On the grounds this trial is unconstitutional! jehe, allery stirs) The defendant is a civilian entitled to a public trial before a jury of her peers. Not a military court- martial.
Military courts adjudicated matters involving civilians throughout the war.
May I remind the distinguished Major the war is over. Moreover, the civi. courts in Washington remained open throughout the entire conflict. And continue to be, as we speak  17.
And may I remind the Senator, the Attorney General affirmed the legitimacy of this proceeding: Holt reaches for a DOCUMENT, which he reads aloud.

"Persons conspiring to assassinate the President -- the Commander -in- Chief -- are considered enemies of the State. And shall be judged by a military tribunal, as would soldiers belonging to a hostile force."
"Soldier!' Surely, no member of this Commission recalls a figure as lovely as this under his command? The Senator playfully draws gattery Ss physique in the ai prompting laughter from the galle
Senator, you will mind the horror which summons us.

Gentlemen, we all mourn the loss of our most cherished leader. But, in our grief, let us not betray our better judgment and execute a reign of terror. MAJOR GENERAL HARRIS, a member of the Military Commission shouts out with a heavy New England accent.
"Reign of Terror.' How dare you!
Every right-minded citizen desires the punishment of those responsible. But one must be judged accor ding to the law -- not as passions see fi
Senator, I assure you this tribunal will make every effort to protect the rights of those on trial. But, all Americans have the right to feel safe and secure.

None of us is safe when a citizen can be dragged from her home, held without charge and denied access to counsel -- merely on a suspicion? Another Commission Member, MAJOR GENERAL KAUTZ, mocks Rev Johnson's southern accent. Kautz is a New Englander.  18.

"Mearlay onah suhspicion.' Sounds to me like the enemy is among us. I recall Maryland was not among our most loyal states during the War. I think its Senator ought to certify his allegiance to this court. BRIGADIER GENERAL HOWE chimes in with his Philadelphia ac
I quite agree. Make him sign.
I have served this nation as its Attorney General. That is certification enough. General Kautz holds up a CONTRACT.
Nevertheless, Senator. We may require counsel to sign this oath of loyalty as prescribed by Congress.
I_am a member of Congress! The branch of government empowered to authorize military tribunals like this.
Our authorization comes from the War Secretary, Edwin Stanton -- by order of the President of the United States.

Had our founding fathers desired tyranny to prevail, I'm sure they'd have intended for the President and his War Secretary to have such indiscriminate powers. (seething) But they drafted a Constitution with laws limiting power, not trusting in human nature to limit itself -- precisely for times like these: (losing his temper) When our leaders claim to be serving the People... when, in fact, they're only serving themselves.
The Gallery erupts. The Prisoners beat iron against wood. General Hunter slams his gavel, repeatedly.
Order...Order...SILENCE! Order is barely RESTORED.
This court will stand in recess. Senator. In chambers!  19. Off Aiken woefully glancing at his Mates, then at Catheri

The prison CORRIDOR outside the generals' CHAMBERS is nea RIOTOUS -- rabid REPORTERS, excited SPECTATORS, and the l Moments later, Reverdy Johnson appears in the hallway wit Aiken in-tow. The inquisitive PRESS converge in a frenzy. Johnson pulls Aiken into a BACK STAIRWELL to escape the hoards. A SOLDIER bars anyone else from following. As Aiken trails his boss upstairs, his face is filled wit panic. The pair are in mid-conversation.
..But you can't be serious.
As serious as the charges against our client.
But defending her? ME!
She doesn't stand a chance with a Southerner like me representing her She needs a Yankee colonel like you.
Yes, but --
-- You'll do fine, son. Our nation still has never executed a woman.
This nation never considered a woman, or aman for that matter, capable of murdering the President. I'm sorry but I can't take on this case.
"Course you can, boy. They taught you somethin' at Harvard, didn't they?

I mean, I won't (off Reverdy s glare) I won't defend he Not someone who murdered my Commander -in-chief. TwO SOLDIERS descend the stairs past Aiken and Reverdy. They are guarding an attractive, unidentified WOMAN, 22. She's just overheard Aiken and stares him down. Aiken uncomfortable, waits for her to pass before continuing.  20.
With all due respect, sir, I'll gladly find you a rebel to represent her.
No court in the Union would judge that woman fairly with Confederate counsel.
Most folks I know wish for her what happened to Booth.
No doubt you'd gladly pull the trigger yourself.
I'd hardly be alone. Aiken points to a CROWD outside the PRISON WALLS -- Linco DEVOTEES holding shrines to Lincoln.
Look at Lincoln now! Remember how so many used to hate him. Now, no one dares utter a word against him, let alone defend his murderer
Alleged, counselor. AIKEN ; You don't honestly believe she's innocent?
'Til proven otherwise.
I will not betray my country, sir. Nor my friends who died in battle defending it. The pair now stand directly in front of the COURTROOM DOO

I'm not suggesting you betray your allegiances. I'm simply asking, rather, telling you to uphold your oath ee an attorney and do your job! eat I demand nothing more. And I assure you, neither your mother or father would've accepted anything less! Aiken wavers.
Sir, I don't see how I can possibly walk in there.  21.
Son, sometimes a man must be willing to 'walk' on faith alone. A beat as we begin to hear...
The conspirators attempted what the confederacy could not accomplish in at FULL SCREEN: On Aiken listening to Holt's opening argumen

To destroy our nation by striking at our chain of command -- targeting not_only our President, but the next in line: his Vice President and Secretary of State. (Aiken looks distressed) That a woman - a mother with children - built the nest where this vile conspiracy was hatched, operating a safe-house for the assassins to meet.
PULL BACK: To reveal Mary over Aiken's shoulder. Both loo equally panicked but for different reasons.
Makes Mary Surratt as guilty of this crime as John Wilkes Booth himself!

A UNION SOLDIER escorts Aiken across the prison grounds - FORTRESS surrounded by BRICK WALLS topped by ARMED SENTRI Just beyond the high walls JAMES CREEK, the foul smelling repository for much of washington" s waste. Blanketing the courtyard is a TENT ENCAMPMENT housing the soldiers, who are guarding the prisoners on trial. Aiken crosses through the encampment. SOLDIERS gather and stare. Some salute Colonel Aiken. Others turn their backs

We continue with Aiken and his armed escort down a long CORRIDOR lined with CELLS -- Each cell is packed with PRISONERS. Some faces are famili the ACTORS being interrogated after Lincoln's assassinati They are still wearing their costumes, now in tatters. Off Aiken's look of confusion, the Guard offers up --
The Witnesses, sir.  22.
How long have they been here?

Coupla months. Aiken is escorted through a pair of huge IRON DOORS. As h continues down a SECOND STORY CATWALK, we REVEAL -- The CONSPIRATORS' CELLS, eight in all. Inside each cell Aiken discovers the same horrifying sight -- a PRISONER, solitary, head covered by a CANVAS HOOD, no slot for seei barely a hole for breathing. Legs and arms are chained to IRON BALLS. Wrists are separated by piercing METAL MANACL
Is all this necessary?
According to orders.
Whose?
Secretary Stanton, sir Aiken lingers momentarily to ponder, then continues towar the FINAL CELL at the end of the corridor.

CELL DOOR number 200 swings opens as Aiken steps inside. MARY is crouching on all fours, chained like a barnyard animal. Though not forced to wear a hood, her ANKLETS and WRIST CUFFS are painfully attached. STRAW is spread benea her; a BUCKET for bodily functions is nearby. The Guard remains at the door
Thank you, private. That'll be all. The Guard doesn't move.
This meeting is confidential.
Sorry, sir.
Where's the Senator? Aiken turns toward Mary.
Ma'am, he's instructed me to handle your case.  23.
Really?
Is there a problem?
No disrespect, Mister...
Frederick Aiken.
Mr. Aiken, how many years have you?
I'm a month past 28.
Young man, you're barely older than my son.
The Senator would not have placed me in this position unless he had complete confidence in my abilities.
I take it then you've handled cases like this before?
Ma'am, there's never been a case like this before.
But, you have defended others? Aiken is silent.
I see they've left nothing to chance.
I take it then you'd prefer to conduct your own defense? A beat. Off Mary's silence, Aiken opens his notes.
Very well. I understand you own a boardinghouse at 604 H Street, is that correct?
Yes. Aiken awaits more information. Mary offers none.  24. Ma'am, all I know about you is what I've read in the papers. And what they're reporting isn't flattering. Mary grudgingly.
I moved there a year ago with my son and daughter after my husband passed away.
The conspirators were frequent visitors to your boardinghouse, were they not? Aiken doesn't even bother to call them alleged conspirato
As were many others.
But, you don't deny having been acquainted with John Wilkes Booth or the other prisoners behind bars?

No, sir. I do not. (sternly) Mr. Aiken, my husband died a drunk leaving me with loads of debt. I had no other way to support my family, except by renting rooms to boarders. I considered those men customers, nothing more. / AIKEN ; ; Did you 'consider' their sentiments?
I did not inquire as to their "sentiments,' sir.
What about yours, ma'am?
I am a Southerner by birth, a Christian by belief, and a devoted mother above all else. And I am NO assassin!
Ma'am, your freedom will depend on far more assurance than that.
Well, then you tell me what I should say to those Generals?  A beat. 25.
Nothing. The rules prohibit you from testifying in your own defense. I suppose you know of someone else who would? Your son, John, perhaps. Any idea where he might be?
I do not. Even at 21, Mr. Aiken he's still my baby. My son will be kept out of this.
That won't be easy, ma'am. He's on the wanted poster.
How about his roommate, Louis Wiechmann? Shall I call on him to testify?
Louie is like a member of my family. I don't want any harm coming to him on account of me.
Is there anyone I can call upon to give your version of events? MARY _ ; ; Who are they calling to give their version?
The Government is not revealing its list of witnesses, or the evidence it plans to use against you.
They can't do that, can they?
This is a military proceeding in which the Government can do just about anything it chooses. Of course, it makes preparing a defense more difficult.
Of course. But what difference does it make? Even these failing eyes of mine can see those Generals made up
their minds -- just by the way they were looking at me.
"Looking" at you?  26.
Just like you, Colonel. A GUARD appears with Mary's dinner, hardly appetizing. Ai heads for the door.
I must go.
Mr. Aiken (Aiken stops) I haven't a word from my daughter since they put me here. Would you check on her for me? Please. He reluctantly nods.
Thank you, Mr. Aiken. I see you've got a spark of human feeling in you after all.

The three-story townhouse seen during the round-up of the alleged assassins. Aiken climbs the front stoop and knock A Union SOLDIER is posted outside her door. Aiken feels a PRESENCE behind -- NEIGHBORS spying from WI and DOORWAYS. Aiken flips his collar to conceal his ident Finally, the boardinghouse DOOR opens.
Anna Surratt? REVEALING: ANNA SURRATT, 22 -- a beautiful young woman wh had to grow up very fast.
My name is Frederick...
I know who you are, Mr. Aiken.
Then you know I'm representing your mother.
I was under the impression you could not -- or rather, "would not". Aiken now places her from the stairwell inside the courth
I'm sorry you heard that. It was meant to be a private conversation. Aiken nervously glances back at the Neighbors.  27.
Are you afraid or just embarrassed to be seen with me, Mr. Aiken?
Your mother asked that I check on you.
If you will be so kind, please tell her not to worry. She begins to close the door.
Actually, I was hoping to get a look inside. He begins to enter. She momentarily blocks his path, then reluctantly steps aside so he can enter.
As Aiken enters the boardinghouse, he surveys the scene.
Are you the only one here?
